Dear Ms. Skinner:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Title Staff to resident ratio.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval
checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 fell asleep while responsible for the supervision of youth
Investigation Attempts were made to contact the complainant on 03/19/2025
and 04/14/2025 and no return contact was made.
Youth A was interviewed on 03/13/2025 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled seeing Staff 1 falling
asleep at night on several occasions. She believed staff were not
supposed to have their phones while supervising youth overnight,
but Youth A would see Staff 1 with her phone in her hand. She
described one instance when she believed Staff 1 had fallen
asleep because the flashlight was turned on her cell phone and it
was in her hand, and Staff 1 was slumped over in her chair
holding the phone. Youth A could not recall any specific dates
when she witnessed this.
Phone contact was attempted with Staff 1 on 04/14/2025 and
04/17/2025 and no return contact was made. Staff 1 no longer is
employed for the agency.
Video reviewed:
• Personnel documentation for Staff 1 was provided. Her
employment was terminated as of 04/04/2025.
• Supervisor 1 assisted with providing security camera
footage during an announced, face-to-face visit at the
facility on 03/26/2025. Staff 1 was viewed working third
shift and supervising sleeping youth on 03/01/2025,
03/06/2025, 03/09/2025, 03/13/2025 and 03/16/2025.
• During the 03/16/2025 footage Staff 1 was seen sitting
in a chair in the unit where the youth are sleeping between
1:00 am-2:00 am. Her posture in the chair was slumped
over, and her right hand was touching her face and
2

appeared to be holding her face up. Her left hand was in
her lap holding her cell phone. During this time Staff 1’s
eyes were closed. Staff 1 did not move for approximately
20 minutes and was asleep.
Documentation reviewed:
• The Chief Administrator confirmed the facility does not
have any policy & procedure specific to overnight staff and
the supervision of youth during sleeping hours.
• Facility program statement was provided and reviewed.
This described supervision of youth provided at ratios of 1
staff to 3 youth during waking hours and 1 staff to 6 youth
during sleeping hours.
• Facility overnight bed check logs of staff’s efforts to provide
eyes on supervision of youth during sleeping hours was
reviewed. Several instances were found where staff
documented eyes on checks of youth in non-varied
intervals, most commonly being documented exactly every
fifteen minutes.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per youth interviews
and documentation Staff 1 fell asleep while supervising youth, as
well as eyes on checks of youth were not in varied intervals.
Technical Assistance
The facility was offered technical assistance to update policy &
procedure specific to the responsibilities and requirements of staff
supervising youth during sleeping hours.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Title Recreational activities, equipment, and supplies; swimming
restriction.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4136
Section (2) Residents shall be provided a variety of indoor and outdoor
Description recreational activities designed to meet the residents' needs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth are not allowed to use the gym for recreation.
Investigation Attempts were made to contact the complainant on 03/19/2025
and 04/14/2025 and no return contact was made.
3

The Chief Administrator was interviewed over the phone on
03/13/2025. She explained the facility’s gymnasium was not
being used at that time because of some property damage caused
by previously placed youth. This included damage to doors that
caused them to not close properly. She confirmed that repairs
were in progress and the plan was to utilize the gym again in the
near future. The Chief Administrator commented that there was
adequate recreation being offered to the youth otherwise. She
described indoor activities such as workout videos and yoga. She
also described outdoor activities such as going for walks through
the facilities wooded areas, playing sports and doing workouts
outside.
Youth A was interviewed on 03/13/2025 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She confirmed the gymnasium
was not in use at that time. She described other recreation
options for the youth placed, including basketball, football and
other activities outside. Youth A stated being outside for
recreation more often at that time because the weather was
warming up. She stated youth mainly read, played cards or board
games and watched movies when inside. Youth A also recalled
doing yoga inside during the winter months.
Youth B was interviewed on 03/13/2025 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She could not recall the last time
the youth were able to use the gym but stated other forms of
recreation included playing basketball and being outside. She
also spoke about playing games and doing fitness videos when
inside.
Youth C was interviewed on 03/13/2025 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth C described various forms
of recreation, including playing basketball outside and doing yoga
and watching movies inside.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 03/26/2025 during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. In reviewing daily logs
and documentation of recreation of youth, Supervisor 1 stated
staff sometimes encounter difficulties in terms of engaging youth
in recreation. When youth declined to participate, it was normal
for staff to offer alternatives. According to Supervisor 1 successful
attempts at recreation included indoor workout videos and playing
basketball outside.
Documentation reviewed:
4

• Facility policy titled “Recreation Policy” was provided and
reviewed. This policy stated that all residents are entitled
to a minimum of 60 minutes of recreation each
day. Examples of common recreation activities listed
included playing sports, aerobics and yoga.
• A sample of Unit Shift Log documentation from the month
of March was provided and reviewed. This showed daily
attempts to provide both group recreation such as workout
videos indoors or playing sports outdoors, as well as
individualized recreation efforts for youth who did not
choose to participate otherwise.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed recreation opportunities
were being sufficiently offered to youth at the facility despite not
having access to the gymnasium.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Title Health services; policies and procedures.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A suffered a head injury and did not receive timely medical
attention.
Investigation Attempts were made to contact the complainant on 03/19/2025
and 04/14/2025 and no return contact was made.
Chief Administrator was interviewed over the phone on
03/13/2025. She reported being aware of Youth A’s complaints
that her head hurt during the month of January, and was aware
there was an instance where a stall door had to be repaired after
Youth A used the bathroom and it fell on her. Chief Administrator
stated she did not believe there was a medical complaint form
filed by Youth A specifically for this instance but would provide
documentation if available.
5

Youth A was interviewed on 03/13/2025 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled the specific incident
described in the allegations where she hit her head. Youth A
stated being in the bathroom that is located near the classrooms
and dining area of the facility. She recalled the door to one of the
stalls coming off of the hinges and hitting her in the head. Youth A
was seen by nursing staff after this occurred. She recalled feeling
dizzy and lightheaded during dinner time afterwards. Youth A
believed she filed a medical complaint to have this addressed on
the same day. Youth A recalled Staff 2 taking her to the hospital
that same day to have her possible injury addressed. Youth A
recalled other occasions where she had been taken to the hospital
on the same day as possible injuries or instances of self-harm but
also commented that she felt the nursing staff at the facility did not
respond timely to medical complaints filed by youth. She could
not provide any other examples of this concern.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 03/26/2025 during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He stated not having
any direct contact with the incident involved in this allegation other
than helping facilitate Youth A being transported to the hospital for
assessment.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone on 04/17/2025. She
recalled the incident in question and taking Youth A to the hospital
the same day. Staff 2 could not recall the specific diagnosis or
instructions for treatment of Youth A, but did confirm Youth A was
not admitted to the hospital on this date and was discharged back
to the facility.
Nurse 1 was interviewed over the phone on 04/25/2025. She
recalled meeting with Youth A in January but could not remember
a specific date. Nurse 1 stated this was done to assess multiple
medical complaints Youth A had submitted. Nurse 1 recalled
Youth A bringing up pain in her head from hitting it on the sink.
Nurse 1 could not recall when that occurred and did not think that
Youth A specified. Nurse 1 did not have concern of any physical
symptoms in speaking with and assessing Youth A but decided
that she should be sent out to urgent care for further evaluation
just in case there was something she could not assess.
Administrator 2 was interviewed over the phone on 05/06/2025.
She recalled becoming aware of the concern that Youth A had
pain and discomfort stemming from hitting her head in a
bathroom. Administrator 2 believed this came from Youth A being
seen by a facility nurse. She recalled being a part of the decision
6

and facilitation of Youth A being taken to urgent care to be seen.
Administrator 2 recalled Youth A being transported by Staff 2.
She did not have any concern that Youth A’s medical needs were
not responded to timely.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 05/07/2025. Staff 3
recalled reporting for his shift and when his work started, he heard
Youth A describing how she had hit her head in the bathroom.
Staff 3 could not recall a specific date for this but believed it was
the third or fourth week of January. Staff 3 recalled Youth A
stating her head hurt “a little,” and over-the-counter pain
medication was offered to her. Staff 3 believed that this
medication offer was not taken by Youth A.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility policy titled “Health and Dental” was provided and
reviewed. This policy stated, “The coordination of all
medical, dental, emergency and crisis related services are
conducted via arrangement with the following community-
based resources/organizations,” with local hospitals listed
for emergency medical needs.
• Facility Health Care Concern & Complaint forms were
provided. Youth A submitted two health concern forms
during January 2025, neither of which referenced any head
pain or discomfort.
• A facility nursing case note dated 01/24/2025 was provided
and reviewed. Facility nursing staff met with Youth A and
assessed the following complaints: sore throat and ear pain
that had since resolved themselves, sinus issues and a
possible injury to her head. In this documentation Youth A
reported that she had “hit her head on the sink when
picking up a paper towel a few days ago.” Nursing staff
performed medical assessments and did not report any
concerns. It was advised that Youth A be sent to urgent
care for evaluation and treatment as indicated.
• No incident reports were written for the instance of Youth A
hitting her head in the bathroom.
• Medical documentation regarding Youth A while she has
been placed at the facility was provided and reviewed.
o Youth A was taken to the hospital on 01/24/2025 to
receive attention to headaches she had experienced
after hitting her head. A prescription for pain
management medication was provided and Youth A
was discharged without being admitted.
7

o Several other instances of Youth A being taken to
local emergencies rooms within the year of 2025
were reviewed.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed Youth A has had sufficient
medical attention provided to her during her placement at the
facility.
Technical Assistance
The facility was offered technical assistance in the area of
documentation of all efforts to provide medical care to youth,
including when incident reports should be written.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV.RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
